threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

Genuine question, do you prefer PAL or NTSC? While I personally understand that PAL has some technical advantages, every time I see a PAL television in operation, the refresh rate bothers me.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9421040
NTA, but I'm from Europe too.
>do you prefer PAL or NTSC?
Well, it depends on the use case.
For 24 fps movies both are kinda shit. NTSC has telecine judder because of the 3:2 pulldown, while in PAL everything is sped up to 25 fps, and while it's not really noticeable until you compare side by side, often the pitch of the audio is higher as a result and it sounds jarring if you're familiar with the original. I'll take a 4K Blu-ray on an OLED here, thank you very much.
TV broadcasts are better in PAL, 50Hz is OK and you get the benefit of a higher resolution and better colors. Of course when we're talking about natively PAL-produced content. Shows converted from one format to the other have their own share of problems.
Now, for games it's NTSC hands down. Most games were produced with NTSC in mind and many PAL ports are broken (speed, aspect ratio, etc.). I have no problem with playing proper PAL conversions though. Of course with NTSC/PAL for games I mean line/refresh standards, not the color encoding. PAL composite looks much better than NTSC, but I don't really care since I use my consoles through RGB SCART.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9421514
Love the SNES original. Didn't care for any of the followups, but REALLY like that one. Played it so much it bled into my bros and I's DND campaign. We'd sit there with the blue light of the paused game illuminating our sessions arguing whether we should keep going on our roleplaying adventures or play another map in Ogre Battle. Good times.

More specifically, really loved the graphics and design of the SNES one. The gold and silver chess pieces were cool. The bright, vivid map colors floating over the blue backdrop makes it warm and inviting, a good balance between pixel-y and artwork. Fun as hell playing around with squad build ideas and finding hidden items to create new and exciting unit types. Favorite was getting a lich named CONAN. The N64 version just didn't do it for me, the look and feel was too much of a departure, and it felt slower overall.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
So how is the class system supposed to work exactly? I get that it's based on the alignment of your characters but if you have say a holy class of low alignment does that nerf the character at all? And does it affect class compatibility of your units if you have holy classes with evil classes?

Love the game btw but there is a bit of an autistic level of complexity to it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9422606
There are level and alignment requirements that must be met in order to upgrade characters into particular classes. It doesn't matter whether or not a character strays outside that alignment range after upgrading, barring the usual things that are impacted by alignment. Mixing "good" and "evil" classes together in a unit has no mechanical impact, but all characters in a unit will trend towards the same alignment over time because they're all getting influenced by the same events, so that could make it hard to upgrade some of them. Upgrading characters into new classes often increases their power dramatically, so keeping characters in the proper alignment range for the classes you're aiming for is a pretty big deal. You don't want to get stuck with a bunch of low-alignment knights that can't become paladins or something.

The game isn't really as complex as it might look at first, alignment and reputation are just a little inintuitive in some ways.

>>9422034

This consumer news report really comes off as a hit piece towards the upcoming Super Nintendo. This is almost counter advertising. But at the same time, parents were upset that the Super Nintendo was not backwards compatible with the NES. There actually was outrage over that. Parents would spend up to $60 a cartridge for their kids NES, spend hundreds of dollars in total over the span of a few years. Find out that the next Nintendo console will not be able to use the old Nintendo software that they paid good money for. Parents didn't want to have a mess of consoles in their living rooms with wires thrown around everywhere. They just wanted to have the one machine that could play all their Nintendo library. Nintendo could never fully communicate why their SNES was not backwards compatible, without sounding like a technical manual. Super Mario AllStars was a weird compromise to everyone, expecting backwards compatibility. Also, this article reminds the audience that Nintendo controls +80% of the market.

here's another 'hit piece' from 1991:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nwd56K7rp7A

This one goes into depth on how Nintendo controlled 80% of the market in North America and could dictate the direction it went in. They use unlicensed software publishers to make arguments.

Also, one of the Toys 'R Us business men at this time stamp, does an involuntary coke snort.

The PC Engine had a very strong grip on the Japanese market long before the Genesis really began gaining steam. Titles like Valis, the Ys series, and various adventure games were very popular over there, and Genesis just didn't have enough of them. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9417234
1 is alright, it's the start of the series. It's enjoyable, but does feel quite primitive after returning to it once you play 3. Japanese version has a save system after each stage boss if you don't want to start over again. It's worth playing a couple of times, until you can clear it in 30 minutes in a single sitting. Doing Second/Third adventure is worth it too.
2 is mundane, even with better translations. Enemies are boring, and their AI/behavior is garbage. Flying enemies fly in a straight line, "hopping" enemies that just hop up and down 3 times, and then they throw them at you with * 10 more hp later on in the game because they expect you to have "whip but slightly longer dealing 3 times more damage". You also have to spam holy water in the castle sections to find secret items, and if you don't have a patch to dampen the sound, prepare to mute your TV or suffer loud shattering noises for the whole duration.
3 is one of the best NES games as long as you avoid Alucard's route, or you deal with tedious falling blocks that last for 5 minutes every continue used and an underpowered side character. Doesn't matter which version you play, all of them have their strengths. There is an exception where Grant is broken in the Japanese version because of his infinite throwable knives allowing him to cheese the whole game, which gets fixed in the US version and even further refined in the PAL version since the enemies and bosses put up a fair fight instead of being frail and easily exploitable as they are in the JP version, or tough as nails in the US version. It's the only game where the PAL version is worth playing.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Whenever I'm looking through libraries of old games for something play I always wonder what happened to all the dead IPs. There used to be so much more variety back then, with big and small budget titles for every console. Some experimental, others trying revolutionize their own genre.
Nowadays you only ever see the famous long-lived companies releasing new games for the same 4~5 franchises they own, naturally because those survived the test of time, and the test of "how much money can we keep making with them".
In some cases they even refuse to acknowledge the existence of certain games that they've developed or published simply because they never sold well enough when competition was fierce, and are only remembered when someone makes a list of fun games of a specific genre for X or Y console. Forgotten Worlds, Captain Commando, Dirt Dash, Gradius, Bloody Roar, Comix Zone, Smashing Drive, all those other arcade machines and third party ventures that barely got two paragraphs worth of a description on Wikipedia, that only amounted to a sporadic "hey remember playing this game?" here or there.

It's just business of course, but I always end up wondering if videogames as a whole have only ever been a process of trimming the wheat from the chaff until you have a couple of golden eggs all along, and if all but the few most profitable titles are gone forever.

PS1 games ran like ass because of bad devs. Very few PS1 games are so filled with TECHNOLOGY that they're simply beyond the PlayStations capabilities.
N64 games ran poorly because of a bad hardware architecture. Games that didn't look like garbage while running well were a rarity.
3DO was just early. Genuinely very few devs knew what the fuck they were doing when it came to 3D.
>Why was sub 60 fps considered okay before the 8th generation of gaming
That's just how it was. SNES and Neo Geo games had massive amounts of slowdown. Doom has a framerate cap of 35fps. Quake ran like shit even on the best hardware at launch.
Sure everyone knew that games could look and run amazing. Daytona USA looked better than anything that would come out for home consoles until the turn of the millenium, but it was also a thirty thousand dollar arcade machine with chips from a military simulator.

last_replies.com:
I used to fastforward/savestate all the time. Now I try to explicitly avoid it, and even if I play on emulators I unbind the keys for it. I have contemplated these concepts for some time and I truly believe that there is value in the experience of playing games like this at their original pace. Part of the adventure is the time you shared with your characters and immersing yourself in the environments and music. It is meditative, in a way. The human brain operates at a certain speed, and moves in and responds to certain beats. We can increase the speed at which we perform mechanical tasks dramatically, but our emotional centers are not so easily adjusted. Fastforwarding through content, even if it seems "irrelevant" on a strict gameplay level, is only cheating yourself of the psychoemotional connection you develop to the experience.

It's ok to take your time.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: It’s far better than you think
threads.com:
Behold, the Bandai wonderswan. The superior 90s handheld that deserves far more credit than it receives

With a library matching the Dreamcast in number and variety, it’s 200 games cover genres that portable gaming frankly sucked at beforehand.

Here you’ll find some of the best strategy RPGs and fighters handhelds ever had to offer in 99.

Backed by the powerhouse that was square, the console got a lot of big name titles from the developer. Final fantasies, mystery dungeons, and a fucking clock tower- the selection of quality RPGs on the console kicks the shit out of what the gameboy color and NGPC was offering that same year.

Being the first handheld with a widescreen, it made real nice for fighting games and vertical puzzlers.

From pocket fighter to guilty gear, to digimon and one piece, the system has a healthy selection of fun brawlers that play very well on the small screen.

On the note of one piece, the console was notable for its anime tie ins. Bandai was a licensing powerhouse after all.

The system was quite capable too! Handily shitting all over the cpus of the gameboy and neo geo pocket- this was the only system of the 3 that could run a full ass web browser.

Nearly the entire library runs at 75 fps. Why? Idk but it’s quite nice. Games are smooth with lots of animation and fast clean scrolling. Hundreds of sprites dotting the screen without hiccup.
The system is no slouch in audio hardware either. Having a capable synth setup, AND cool ass sample capabilities- it has a sound that when used to full potential reminds me of some neo geo titles.

Despite the device being a properly capable 16 bit handheld for the time, the thing SIPS power. A single AA battery will keep the thing in active gameplay for well over 40 hours. That’s not 40 hours standby- that’s 40 hours of straight gameplay. On ONE battery. Gbc could barely muster 10 on 2 of the things.
This was also a console that only cost about $30 on release.

threads.com:
>Gadget is hard to describe. Surreal and unsettling would be a good place to start. A weird curio from a bygone era? Yep. An avant-garde art piece? Yeah, probably that too. I'm hesitant to call it a good game, because it's barely a game at all, but I'll certainly say this... it's interesting.

>The game is extremely linear, mostly shuffling you around from location to location with a few things in any given environment to interact with and, once you do, you'll be shuffled off to the next area. This has the effect, intended or not, of making you feel rather uncomfortable as you're given virtually no control over anything. Practically every game amounts to simply doing what the developers intended, but it's rarely as on the nose as it is here, to the point that it feels less like exerting your own will and intellect to reach a desired conclusion that was planned by the developers and more like doing what they want, regardless of what you want. The distinction is arguably superficial but, in this case, it's palpable just the same.

>Graphically the game is a strange mishmash of steampunk, art deco, and some kind of unidentified Eastern Bloc country aesthetic. Things frequently take a turn for the surreal, and you often travel from one location to the next in something approximating an out of body experience - you'll be looking at a monitor of something and then suddenly move through the monitor into that location, for example.

>Adding to the surreal and unsettling quality is a fantastic, otherworldly soundtrack by Koji Ueno. It sometimes reminded me of the work of Akira Yamaoka, with things frequently turning into walls of abstract industrial noise. If the bizarre visuals and storytelling aren't enough to make you uneasy, the music ought to do the trick.

https://www.zombs-lair.com/gadget-collection

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
My parents actually skipped dial-up. We had a computer (Macintosh Performa 631CD from Sears), but it didn't have a modem or any networking of any kind, and didn't communicate with the outside world. My first online experience was playing Starcraft with my friends over Battlenet, on our then-new iMac with a 768k DSL connection. It was an absolutely mind-blowing, magical experience. I completely skipped over the janky 56k experience most people had, and jumped into what online gaming was supposed to be.

>>9419753
I remember the wait for the Mac OS version of UT99. All my friends got the game for Christmas of 1999 and they were all playing each other online, but the Mac OS version was inexplicably delayed to January of the following year. I missed out on a lot in those three weeks but I'm glad for the good times playing that game in the early 2000s. I agree something's been lost, modern servers definitely don't have the same vibe, and it's not just me getting older.

>>9419790
I actually still play Brood War and Rise of Nations with my friends. Aside from that it's been years since I've played online with random people, it's just not something I enjoy anymore.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9419740
Do MUDs and BBS door games count? Cause those, really. The Pit, Usurper, Solar/Barren Realms Elite, many others I have trouble remembering. Great times rushing home from school, being the first one to log onto all the BBSes me and my friends did the rounds on (one user at a time, remember!), and getting my 30 minutes of play in on each game.
Some BBSes had multiple lines so there was a mild amount of simultaneous play, I think Usurper had some. Of course there was LORD as well, but I always thought that game felt a little sloppy (so obviously it became the most famous).

"Real" simultaneous multiplayer came into play for me with a game called Crossroads on one of the rare large BBSes with 20+ lines available. It was a simplified MUD-like text adventure/RPG and you could move around and attack other players or team up. Eventually that BBS added an internet connection and had a special feature where you could connect to a unix shell and telnet around to real MUDs to your heart's content and that's when things got amazing. Made a lot of friends on my chosen MUD, even used to send photos back and forth and there was a live meetup once. It would still be a few years later till technology advanced, everyone got their own home internet connections, and MMOs like Everquest, UO, and Asheron's Call emerged on the scene.

Before that though, I played Doom with friends over a direct house-to-house modem connection, that was fun. Getting Quake to work in a DOS tcp/ip stack and connecting to my first 32 player server was INSANE, though. It was too buggy to even play properly but every second of it was mindblowing.

The image is outright photobashed from a still of the old Sylvester Stallone Judge Dredd movie, where he's holding a pump-action shotgun decked out in a sci-fi shell.

These typically take place when no one is likely to be working in the office so that there are no changes to the source code during the build. The results of the build are inspected by the arriving programmers, who generally place a priority on ensuring the recent changes to the source code have not broken the build process or functionality of the software. Nightly builds also ensure that the build tools have not broken due to system updates, and are therefore often run whether any source code has changed or not.

>A Treasure Ship, also called the White Ship or Coin Ship, is a wandering Hammer Brother that has been turned into a coin-filled airship that appears in Super Mario Bros. 3. If Mario or Luigi ventures onto a Treasure Ship, he finds tons of coins that he can collect, plus a Hidden Block with a 1-Up Mushroom (which is blue in the NES version).

>Treasure Ships are summoned through a trick that must be performed by following a specific method:
>The player must be in either World 1: Grass Land, World 3: Water Land, World 5: Sky Land, or World 6: Ice Land.
>A wandering Hammer Brother must be on the world map.
>Mario or Luigi must finish a stage with a coin total ending in a multiple of 11 (zero does not count).
>The tens digit of the player's score must match the multiple of 11 (i.e., if the coin total is 11, the tens digit must be 1; if the coin total is 22, the tens digit must be 2; and so on).
>As each second left on the timer will award the player 50 points, the timer must be stopped on an even number so that the number of points received is a multiple of 100. Alternatively, an odd number will work if the score is 50 points off from the correct multiple.
>For instance, if the above criteria are met, and the player ends a stage with 44 coins and a score of 0246240, they will successfully trigger a Treasure Ship. It should be noted that this trick will work only once in any given world.

I bought this for Gamecube earlier this month. There’s no input lag whatsoever and if anything, I hit the fireball in MMX1 and uppercut in MmX2 better than ever.

Be warned though, the sound is kind of shit in the SNES games, you’ll hear some weird noises when you use storm Eagle’s weapon etc. But the games are overall a bit smother, you won’t get a shitload of slowdown when you blow up the sub marine or have too much happening at once.

MMX5 uses the dumb Guns and Roses names for the Mavericks, but that’s how it originally was I guess. Some of the text looked like it was screwed up too.

threads.com:
I just realized something that is a very big mark against Shenmue for me, even as a fan. The game aims to be realistic, so clearly that means that you won't be fighting every 30 seconds like its a Yakuza game, however, because of the lack of fighting it feels as if I never have the chance to get good at the actual combat. I noticed that every battle feels like me testing out moves to see if they work, like I'm fumbling around in practice mode in a fighting game, I never feel like I have the hang of this games fighting mechanics. Its not as if I lose the fights, but its never very satisfying because once I try and fail to be technical and thoughtful with my attack selection, I just default to mashing, regroup, and win anyway.

Perhaps its just me but it feels like a profound revelation right now.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: 5th console generation was the real golden age
threads.com:
People often say that 4th gen was the golden age, specifically SNES, because, because 2D matured enough to look good, while 5th gen was the period of experimentation and early 3D and thus did not age well. In fact, this is correct only for side scrolling platformer games. Genre by genre, 5th gen was the period when many genres, which were miserable during 4th gen, finally became great.
>Fighting games.
4th gen only had Street Fighter 2 ports which are still good. All other fighting games were compromised in various ways and are hard to get back to. Mortal Kombat, World Heroes, Art of Fighting, Fatal Fury - these were okayish 7.5/10 in arcades but home ports sucked big time with possible exception of SNES MK2. You didn't have great fighting experience on home consoles.
On 5th gen you have literal masterpieces like VF2, Tekken 2 and 3, SF Alpha games and other Capcom and SNK ports. Even on PS1, which is considered less desireable than Saturn for 2D fighting games, things like SFA or Real Bout shit all over any of the SNES or Genesis ports.
>Racing games
This is even easier. Daytona USA, Ridge Racer, Sega Rally, Gran Turismo, Need for Speed - these all are huge system sellers and still play great. SNES and Genesis have tons of racing games but they all are shovelware. Nothing on the level and prominence of the titles mentioned above. Out Run was good only on arcades.
>First person shooters
5th gen had Doom, Quake and Goldeneye. Nuff said. SNES Doom is more of a curiosity than a proper game. 16 bit consoles only had Wolfenstein and Zero Tolerance which is a Wolfenstein clone - both very simplistic and flat, compared to Doom.
>Real Time Strategy
There is Dune 2 on Genesis and that's it. Herzog Zwei is a strategy/shmup hybrid and is a different genre. Dune 2 is a very barebones game with only skirmish missions, bad controls and tons of slowdown. 5th gen consoles have proper RTS games with C&C, Red Alert and Warcraft 2 ports.
